question_text: According to the review paper by Wang et al. (2017), what is the role of the Distributed Activation Energy Model (DAEM) in biomass pyrolysis research, and how does it address the multiscale complexity of biomass structures?
standard_answer: The Distributed Activation Energy Model (DAEM) serves as one of several macroscopic kinetic modeling methods developed to simulate mass loss behavior during biomass pyrolysis. As stated in the paper: 'Based on experimental results, many macroscopic kinetic modeling methods with comprehensive mechanism schemes, such as the distributed activation energy model (DAEM), isoconversional method, detailed lumped kinetic model, kinetic Monte Carlo model, have been developed to simulate the mass loss behavior during biomass pyrolysis and to predict the resulting product distribution.' The DAEM approach is particularly valuable because it addresses the fundamental challenge that 'the multiscale complexity of the biomass structures and reactions involved in pyrolysis make it challenging to elucidate the mechanism.' This complexity arises from biomass's heterogeneous composition of cellulose, hemicellulose, and lignin, each with distinct thermal decomposition characteristics and activation energies. By employing a distribution of activation energies rather than a single value, DAEM can better represent the diverse chemical bonds and structural variations within biomass components, providing more accurate predictions of pyrolysis behavior across different temperature regimes and biomass types.
